text.p: These are the
highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.
GAZETA MERCANTIL
-- BIG FIRMS SEE TIGHT 1997

Six of Brazil's largest listed companies see 1997 as another year of adjustments with economic growth around 4 percent, inflation below 10 percent, nominal interest rates at 18-22 percent and a $5 billion trade deficit.
-- BAMERINDUS IS TOO BIG TO FAIL

Francisco Abreu, analyst with U.S. credit rating firm Moody's, is confident Brazil will find a solution for the troubles of the country's fourth largest private bank Bamerindus which is simply "too big to fail".
-- BNDES AIMS TO BECOME BRAZIL'S 'EXIMBANK'

Brazil's National Development Bank (BNDES) is on its way to become the country's "Eximbank" as of January 1997 by introducing more competitive export financing and implementing new mechanisms for export guarantees.
O GLOBO
-- FLUMINENSE FANS ATTACK OPPONENTS
Fans of Rio de Janeiro's Fluminense soccer team invaded the soccer pitch and attacked players of the Atletico-PR team from Parana state after Fluminense lost two to three.
-- SUNDAY ON THE BEACH SEES REINFORCED SECURITY
Police presence on Rio de Janeiro's beaches on the weekends has been reinforced for the summer season to prevent crime waves.
FOLHA DE SAO PAULO
-- HOMICIDES TRIPLE IN BRAZIL
In the 15 years between 1979 and 1994 the number of homicides in Brazil has tripled from 11,194 to 32,350, making Brazil's murder rate one third higher than that of the United States.
-- TEENAGERS TO PARTICIPATE IN CHRISTMAS WITHOUT HUNGER
The campaign "Christmas without Hunger" which aims to distribute 500,000 baskets of basic goods to needy families across Brazil wants teenagers to take part in the campaign.
Reuters has not verified the stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
-- Simona de Logu, Rio de Janeiro newsroom, 5521 507 4151
